title: Hold on my personal banking account from sheriff, what to do?? Does this ruin my credit more?
question: I defaulted on my credit card payments when I was laid off. After I was able to get a stable job, I enrolled in a debt solution monthly payment plan. However, not all credit account agreed to enroll. For the accounts that did not accept, I was unable to make the additional payments they were asking for and now the sheriff placed a hold on my personal banking account. What am I suppose to do now? Will they except a payment plan and remove the hold? Does this further worsten my credit?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Default judgment
answers:
File a claim of exemption, Cal. Judicial Council Form EJ-160, see link below to the forms, which you can complete for free and press print, then sign it and make extra copies, to file with the Levying Officer (the sheriff's office that delivered the papers to the bank). Boxes 3-6 are the most important in your situation. You should look at the list of exemptions on EJ-155 for ideas. There may be a hearing that you will need to attend and bring documents to prove to the judge your exemption should be granted.

If the defendant was not properly served with the summons and complaint, then the judgment may be able to be set aside by a motion to set aside default judgment. I usually recommend that the defendant hire an attorney for this, as the Judicial Counsel has no fill in the box form for this and there are all sorts of time restrictions that can apply, so dealing with this promptly once learning of the default judgment and lawsuit is important. If you were served with the lawsuit and the judgment is under six months old, there still may be time ti set it aside, but acting promptly is key. I have done many motions to set aside for people and the facts are always different and what the judge needs to be convinced also depends on the situation. There is no cookie cutter, in my opinion, though some evidence is more persuasive than other evidence to many judges. If the judge sets aside a default judgment, then the judge still must determine the case on its merits. That may or may not go well for the defendant, so setting aside a default judgment is only part of the battle.

Credit concerns are important, but take a back seat to resolving this judgment, such as by satisfaction of judgment, set aside and settlement, or discharge. If the judgment is set aside or satisfied, that will help your credit when your credit report is updated to reflect the resolution. If not settled, a judgment can remain on the debtor's credit report until satisfied in full or discharged. My office handles these cases. I offer free consultations. The reason that the Sheriff levied upon your bank account is because you were served with a Summons and Complaint in a lawsuit. You either went to court and lost, or you did not appear. The creditor is entitled to levy on all of your assets that are not exempt from execution. You can file a Claim of Exemption with the Sheriff if you need the money for necessities of life. You can file bankruptcy. If you were not properly served with Summons and Complaint, or have some other reason for not going to court, you can file a motion to vacate the judgment. You will need an attorney to prepare the motion papers because there is no pre-printed court form.

Your attorney will need to review relevant documents in the court's file. These are public records that you can get by going to the courthouse.
